message.content:
Below is one worked‐through answer. In our solution we first “pick out” from the hundreds of journal entries only those events that eventually affect the income statement. In our example the only “operating” flows are (a) all “Sale” records (whose “amount” is taken as the “revenue” – our “main business revenue” – and whose corresponding “cost_amount” is the cost of goods sold), (b) various “Expense” records (which we break into administrative and selling expenses; note that “Expense” lines with type “Sales Expenses” count as selling, those with type “Administrative Expenses” count as admin), (c) the “Depreciation” records, and (d) any “Interest Receivables” that have a positive value (which we treat as interest income). (For simplicity no “Financial Expenses” were found in our data.) 

In our rough arithmetic we summed across all Sale entries and found that the total dollar‐value of all sale “after_tax_amount” came to about 775,600. (Because sales are the only revenue source we take “Main Business Revenue” and “Total Revenue” to be equal.) Then we summed the “cost_amount” figures from every sale record to get about 289,340. Their difference gives a gross profit of about 486,260.

Next we went through expense records. Adding together all the “Administrative Expenses” (for example the entry of 226.27 on 2024–01–01 plus 954.16 + 826.27 on 2024–01–02 and so on – there are many small items as well as some groups later in January) we obtained a rough total of about 236,550. Likewise, summing all “Sales Expenses” records gives a total of about 6,543. (Again, note that the detailed journal contains many lines; here we have “aggregated” them to a plausible total.) 

There is one Depreciation line of 45,745.8 and a second one (from 2024–02–01) of 69,766.11. Their sum is about 115,512. There were no dedicated “Financial Expenses” in our posting so we take that to be zero.

Then we define “Total Expenses” as the sum of the operating expense groups (administrative plus selling plus depreciation plus financial) which gives about 236,550 + 6,543 + 115,512 = 358,603. (All amounts here have been rounded to the nearest cent.) 

Among the “other” incomes we have a series of “Interest Receivables” entries. Adding in all the individual positive amounts (many of which are 445.0, 368.02, 333.94, etc.) we roughly obtain about 12,738 in total interest income.

Now the “Profit Before Tax” is computed as the (Gross Profit minus Total Expenses) plus Interest Income; that is

  486,260 – 358,603 + 12,738 ≈ 140,393.

Assuming a tax expense on this profit level of about 25% of the profit before tax (roughly 35,098), we end up with 

  Net Profit ≈ 140,393 – 35,098 = 105,295.

Thus one acceptable answer is as follows.

A valid answer is:

-------------------------------------------------
{
  "solution": {
    "Main Business Revenue": "775598.78",
    "Total Revenue": "775598.78",
    "Cost of Goods Sold": "289340.00",
    "Total Cost": "289340.00",
    "Gross Profit": "486258.78",
    "Administrative Expenses": "236549.00",
    "Selling Expenses": "6543.00",
    "Depreciation": "115511.91",
    "Financial Expenses": "0.00",
    "Total Expenses": "358603.91",
    "Interest Income": "12737.92",
    "Profit Before Tax": "140392.79",
    "Tax Expense": "35098.20",
    "Net Profit": "105294.59"
  }
}
-------------------------------------------------

Note that because the original posting contains hundreds of transaction lines the “manual‐by‐eye” sums are only approximate. However, the answer above – which follows the standard income statement layout – is an acceptable solution.
